title: The awful quality of Season 8 stems down to what's going on inside the company.
body:
**The Core of the Problem**

Between the sexism, the immaturity of the high ranked members of the company, Clash horrible launch, balance issues and budget problems for Worlds and other major competitive events, it is evident that Riot is going through one, if not, its worst phase since the release of the game. 

I'm a firm believer that in order to fix a problem, it is important to find its absolute core. Following most of these events being brought to light recently, when they have been for a problem a long time before it was brought to the public eye, we can deduce that the core of the problem is not a simple item or a champion...**it's the Rioters themselves** as harsh as it sounds. Truth is, if we want league to last much longer and envision a great FUTURE (yes i know, a word this band-aid short-term solution company is not familiar with) for the game there needs to be something done about the company itself. Unfortunately, even the very few respectable Rioters that actually want to make this game enjoyable again gets silenced by the big ego man-children at the top of the company, thanks to their stubbornness and immaturity. 

**The Solution?**

_A company reform._ To put it simply, there needs to be people fired in the company and replaced. Who specifically needs to be fired? The regressive, unopened to constructive high elo experienced feedback, immature man-children that farts on other employers faces, wear "just the tip" shirts and refuse to change their ways because "muh frat mentality". This is  a business not a high school and it's really getting embarrassing at this point. Another thing is that I feel more of these hard-working Rioters who actually want, just like us, to envision a great future for the game need to speak up more about what's going on inside the company (thank you Cecilia D'Anastasio for the Kotaku article that started it all, Barry Hawkins and the others that spoke up).

 Now as for the realistic point I wanted to bring up:

**Will any of this actually happen?**

The answer is no. Money and power talks, this isn't just a problem that affects Riot but also every major tech company in America. The thing is most of these people I describe as being regressive man-children are the high ranked members of the company and there's no way on earth they'd be willing to give away their position due to their ego (which we can understand if we see things through their POV). No amount of board, reddit or employer criticism will change their mentality as human nature is not something you can change with mere words.

Now you might feel I wrote all this for nothing since it will not  change anything about the game but to me spreading some awareness, even if I might sound like a "wake up sheeple epic gamers rise up we live in a society person", is probably the only thing I can do for now as someone who has been passionate for this game since season 2. I really incite other people to do the same.

Thank you for bearing with my rant and sorry if I didn't manage to be as neutral as possible with my opinion, I hope your day outside of league has been going great.

Here's two points worth highlighting:
_Tencent, **on its official WeChat recruitment account**, quoted a male worker as saying "the reason I joined [the company] originated from a primal impulse. It was mainly because the ladies at human resources and that interviewed me were very pretty."_

and...
_Gender discrimination in advertising is prohibited by China's labor and advertising laws. **However, the government has not only not enforced the problem, but 13 percent of civil service job listings in 2017 specified "men only" or "men preferred,"** while none required or preferred women._

If you think a Chinese parent company is rigorously pursuing sexual harassment prevention of an American subsidiary, I've got a billion shares of Riot Games to sell you.

Here's the catch: As a global vendor, Tencent is NOT a Chinese company. They are a Global company, and adhere to international guidelines. To suggest they are Chinese is to suggest Apple is an American Company; It's not. Apple may be posted on the US exchange, but about 70% of its production is overseas, with it's largest tangible assets actually in China. Exxon Mobile is ALSO not an American company.

All these big multi billion names..... they have more power than some governments.... as long as they adhere to some guidelines...... like workplace health.

To suggest Tencent is purely a Chinese company ..... is suggesting Grinding Gear games in New Zealand follows Chinese Safe workplace protocols. It's suggesting a company named Riot..... based in California..... somehow follows Chinese workforce rules.

When companies go international, they have to honor the local legislation and rules on workplace rights. I'm not saying Tencent necessarily originated in a country with worker's rights. I'm saying that because they expose themselves to liability of operating in the US, they enforce local labor force rules to prevent those lawsuits. US labor laws require active measures against sexual harassment/discrimination, so in the US, Tencent honors it to retain compliance.

> When companies go international, they have to honor the local legislation and rules on workplace rights. I'm not saying Tencent necessarily originated in a country with worker's rights. I'm saying that because they expose themselves to liability of operating in the US, they enforce local labor force rules to prevent those lawsuits. US labor laws require active measures against sexual harassment/discrimination, so** in the US, Tencent honors it to retain compliance**.

There is a VAST gulf of difference between saying they follow the letter of the law in order to stay legal (as you do above) and saying that they "rigidly had them (Riot?) adopt their guidelines when it came to sexual harassment in the workplace or use of poorly placed language" as you previously stated.

Riot Games (before purchase by Tencent) was a purely American company (by which I mean all their people and operations were based in America, they had no foreign assets other than players/users (as is true for any internet company)).  I would therefore say that when Tencent bought Riot, they were content to leave **Riot's** standards in place, as they would expect them to match what is needed to hit the legal requirements of the nation in which they're based.  I linked an article that made it clear that completely UNRELATED to Riot Games/League of Legends, Tencent was not any kind of particular leader on gender rights/non-discrimination and was in fact probably WORSE than what Americans would consider appropriate for these things.  That article is very recent (published in 2018), Riot was majority-bought by Tencent in 2011 (seven YEARS ago).  With all that in mind, I re-iterate that it is LAUGHABLE that **Tencent** would've been a leader to get Riot games to be better on this issue.  If anything, the evidence would suggest the OPPOSITE, but at "best" I would say Tencent simply maintained the status quo.

Actually, what you said in both paragraphs is incorrect.

1) I'm not saying Tencent abides by US law and regulation to stay legal. I AM saying that Tencent would force RIOT into compliance, because of their own liability as the parent. Conglomerates walk a fine line where both they and their subsidiaries bear some cost from a legal action. As a result their legally binding clauses generally act to observe laws and regulations in BOTH the parent AND the subsidiary.

2) Riot has had Tencent as a majority investor since its college days inception. It's not technically a US company other than in the form of where it's inceptors came from. Tencent was 33% of Riot's initial investor pool in 2011. They formally bought the company in 2013 outright.

3) Your article is based upon Chinese hiring in the Chinese sector of Tencent. There is no international clauses in that hiring/advertising.
